text: <@U01NM31CTFU> Just joined this Slack today so I'm late to this thread and you may have already decided how to move forward, but I'm reading back through this channel and found this post interesting. I'd like to suggest that if you have to bribe people who are already getting paid for the work to get them to perform according to the agreement (a la the raffle you proposed), then you're either not paying them enough to make the job attractive OR they're just not good contractors and you should move on and find new ones.  Similarly, I think you're probably wasting your time to give writers a checkmark on the chalkboard and detention when they get three. If they're late without being a good communicator about it, you should dismiss them. You're running a business, not an elementary school. :slightly_smiling_face:

text: All very good points <@U02CMUQ7494>. I do think that writers/creatives require unique types of management if you want to reduce churn. But I've basically decided to do a three strike system and auto assignment reassignment if you're a no call no show with a deadline. Everyone (regardless of if they're a writer or not) on my team at the end of the year gets a bonus.
